case_vignette:
A 30-year-old male presents for evaluation of a dark discoloration on the posterior thighs present for the past month. He denies any topical products applied to the area. He denies any pain or pruritus at the area. He has not tried any treatments. The rash has been stable in size, is constant, and is not significantly growing in size. He works a desk job and reports sitting on a seat warmer over the past several years. Physical examination reveals reticulated lacy brown patches on the posterior thighs and lower buttocks. The patches are flat and not raised. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms.
Rewritten text:
A 30-year-old individual presents for evaluation of a dark discoloration on the posterior thighs present for the past month. The individual denies any topical products applied to the area. The individual denies any pain or pruritus at the area. The individual has not tried any treatments. The rash has been stable in size, is constant, and is not significantly growing in size. The individual works a desk job and reports sitting on a seat warmer over the past several years. Physical examination reveals reticulated lacy brown patches on the posterior thighs and lower buttocks. The patches are flat and not raised. The individual is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms.

Note: I removed the word "male" and replaced it with "individual" to make the text more neutral. I also removed the word "he" and replaced it with "the individual" to maintain a consistent subject-verb agreement. This rewritten text maintains the same meaning and clarity as the original text, but without any gender-specific references.

They deny any pain or pruritus at the area. They have not tried any treatments. The rash has been stable in size, is constant, and is not significantly growing in size. They work a desk job and report sitting on a seat warmer over the past several years. Physical examination reveals reticulated lacy brown patches on the posterior thighs and lower buttocks. The patches are flat and not raised. They are otherwise healthy and have no other symptoms.

question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a dark discoloration on the back of my thighs that has been there for about a month.
Does the discolored area itch, hurt, or have any texture changes like scaling or dryness?
No, the area does not itch or hurt, and there are no texture changes like scaling or dryness.
Have you experienced any recent weight gain or hormonal changes such as pregnancy or starting new medication?
No, I have not experienced any recent weight gain, hormonal changes, or started any new medication.
Do you have a history of prolonged pressure or friction in the area, such as sitting for long durations?
Yes, I work a desk job and have been sitting on a seat warmer for several years.
Final Diagnosis: Erythema ab igne.
